text: Instead we should write a letter telling them to abstain from things polluted by idols, from sexual immorality, from what is strangled, and from blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: For from ancient times Moses has had those who proclaim him in every city, since he is being read in the synagogues every Sabbath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the apostles and the elders, together with the whole church, thought it would be best to choose men from their group to send to Antioch along with Paul and Barnabas, namely, Judas, called Barsabbas, and Silas, who were leading men among the brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They wrote this letter for them to deliver:
From the apostles and the elders, your brothers,
To the Gentile brothers in Antioch, Syria, and Cilicia:
Greetings.
speaker: Narrator

text: We heard that there were some who came from us without our authorization and caused you distress by unsettling your minds with what they said.
speaker: Narrator

text: So it seemed best to us, since we are of one mind, to choose some men to send to you, along with our dear friends Barnabas and Paul,
speaker: Narrator

text: men who have risked their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore we have sent Judas and Silas, who will report these same things by word of mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it seemed best to the Holy Spirit and to us to put no greater burden on you than these essentials:
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are to abstain from food sacrificed to idols, from blood, from what has been strangled, and from sexual immorality. If you carefully avoid these things, you will do well.
Farewell.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they were sent on their way, they went down to Antioch. They gathered the congregation together and delivered the letter.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people read it and rejoiced over its encouraging message.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judas and Silas, who were prophets themselves, also said much that encouraged and strengthened the brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they had spent some time there, they were sent off by the brothers with the greeting of peace to those who had sent them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul and Barnabas remained in Antioch, where they, along with many others, kept on teaching and preaching the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a time Paul said to Barnabas, “Let’s return and visit the brothers in every town where we have preached the word of the Lord and see how they are doing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Barnabas wanted to take John, who is called Mark, along with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul did not think it was a good idea to take him along, since he had deserted them in Pamphylia and did not continue to travel with them in the work.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had such a sharp disagreement that they parted company. Barnabas took Mark with him and sailed away to Cyprus,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Paul chose Silas and set out, after being entrusted to the grace of the Lord by the brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went through Syria and Cilicia, strengthening the churches.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul arrived in Derbe and in Lystra, where there was a disciple named Timothy, who was the son of a believing Jewish woman, but his father was a Greek.
speaker: Narrator

text: The brothers in Lystra and Iconium spoke well of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul wanted Timothy to accompany him, so he took him and circumcised him on account of the Jews who lived in those places, because they all knew that his father was a Greek.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they traveled through the towns, they delivered the resolutions decided by the apostles and elders in Jerusalem for the people to keep.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the churches were strengthened in the faith and increased in number day by day.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went through the region of Phrygia and Galatia, because they were prevented by the Holy Spirit from speaking the word in the province of Asia.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they went as far as Mysia, they tried to go into Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus did not allow them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they passed by Mysia and went down to Troas.
speaker: Narrator

text: A vision appeared to Paul during the night. A Macedonian man was standing there, urging him, “Come over to Macedonia and help us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he had seen the vision, we immediately made plans to proceed to Macedonia, because we concluded that God had called us to preach the good news to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: After we put out to sea from Troas, we sailed straight to Samothrace, and the next day to Neapolis.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there we went to Philippi, which is a leading city in that part of Macedonia and a Roman colony. We stayed in this city for a number of days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the Sabbath day we went outside the city gate alongside the river, where we thought there was a place of prayer. We sat down and began to talk to the women who had gathered there.
speaker: Narrator

text: A woman named Lydia, who worshipped God, was listening. She was a dealer in purple cloth from the city of Thyatira. The Lord opened her heart to pay close attention to what Paul was saying.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she and her household were baptized, she urged us, “If you consider me a believer in the Lord, come and stay at my house.” And she persuaded us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once when we were going to the place of prayer, a slave girl met us. She had a spirit that foretold the future, and she made a large profit for her owners by fortune-telling.
speaker: Narrator

text: As she followed Paul and us, she kept crying out, “These men are servants of the Most High God, who are proclaiming to you the way to be saved.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When she kept doing this for many days, Paul became so annoyed that he turned to the spirit and said, “I command you in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her!” And it came out at that very moment.
speaker: Narrator

text: When her owners saw that their hope of making money was gone, they seized Paul and Silas and dragged them into the marketplace before the authorities.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had brought them to the magistrates and said, “These men are throwing our city into a state of confusion. They are Jews,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they are teaching customs that are not lawful for us to accept or practice, since we are Romans.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the crowd also joined in the attack against them, the magistrates tore off their clothes and ordered them to be beaten with rods.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they had beaten them severely, they threw them into prison and ordered the jailer to guard them securely.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because he received such a command, the jailer threw them into the inner prison and fastened their feet in the stocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: About midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God, and the prisoners were listening to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly there was such a violent earthquake that the foundations of the prison were shaken. Instantly all the doors were opened, and everyone’s chains came loose.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the jailer woke up and saw that the prison doors were opened, he drew his sword and was about to kill himself, because he thought that the prisoners had escaped.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul shouted with a loud voice, “Don’t harm yourself, because we are all here!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The jailer called for lights, rushed in, and fell down trembling in front of Paul and Silas.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought them outside and asked, “Sirs, what must I do to be saved?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “Believe in the Lord Jesus and you will be saved, you and your household.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They spoke the word of the Lord to him and to everyone in his home.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the same hour of the night, he took them and washed their wounds. Without delay, he and all his family were baptized.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought Paul and Silas into his house and set food before them. He rejoiced, because he and his whole household had come to believe in God.
speaker: Narrator

text: At daybreak the magistrates sent officers, saying, “Release those men!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The jailer reported these words to Paul: “The magistrates have sent orders that you should be released. So come out now and go in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul said to them, “They beat us publicly without a trial, even though we are Roman citizens, and threw us into prison. And now they are releasing us secretly? Absolutely not! Let them come themselves and escort us out!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The officers reported these words to the magistrates, and they were afraid when they heard that Paul and Silas were Roman citizens.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they came and apologized to them. As they escorted them out, they requested that they leave the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Paul and Silas came out of the prison, they went to Lydia’s house. They saw the brothers, encouraged them, and then left.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Paul and Silas had traveled through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they came to Thessalonica, where there was a Jewish synagogue.
speaker: Narrator

text: As was his custom, Paul went to the Jews, and on three Sabbath days he led them in a discussion from the Scriptures,
speaker: Narrator

text: explaining and proving that the Christ had to suffer and rise from the dead. He also said, “This Jesus I am proclaiming to you is the Christ.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of them were persuaded and joined Paul and Silas, as did a great number of God-fearing Greeks and more than a few of the prominent women.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Jews became jealous and gathered from the marketplace some wicked men, who formed a mob and started a riot in the city. They rushed to Jason’s house and searched for Paul and Silas in order to bring them out to the mob.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they did not find them, they dragged Jason and some of the brothers before the city officials, shouting, “These men, who have stirred up trouble all over the world, have come here too,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Jason has welcomed them as guests! They are all acting contrary to Caesar’s decrees, saying that there is another king, Jesus!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The crowd and the city officials were stirred up when they heard these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took a security bond from Jason and the others and then let them go.
speaker: Narrator

text: That same night, the brothers sent Paul and Silas away to Berea. When they arrived, they went into the Jewish synagogue.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Bereans were more noble-minded than the Thessalonians. They received the word very eagerly and examined the Scriptures every day to see if these things were so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many of them believed, along with more than a few prominent Greek women and men.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the Jews in Thessalonica learned that the word of God was being proclaimed by Paul in Berea, they also went there to agitate and stir up the crowds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the brothers immediately sent Paul away to the seacoast, but Silas and Timothy stayed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who escorted Paul brought him all the way to Athens. When they left, they received instructions for Silas and Timothy to join Paul as soon as possible.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Paul was waiting for them in Athens, he was very distressed to see that the city was full of idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he led a discussion in the synagogue with the Jews and those who feared God, as well as with those who happened to be in the marketplace every day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers also debated with him. Some said, “What is this seed picker trying to say?” Others said, “He seems to be someone who is proclaiming foreign gods.” They said this because Paul was preaching the good news about Jesus and the resurrection.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took him and brought him to the council of the Areopagus, saying, “May we know what this new teaching is that you are talking about?
speaker: Narrator

text: You seem to be bringing in some ideas that are strange to our ears, so we want to know what these things mean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (All the Athenians and the foreigners who lived there enjoyed doing nothing more than telling or listening to something new.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul stood up in front of the council of the Areopagus and said, “Men of Athens, I see that you are very religious in every way.
speaker: Narrator

text: For as I was walking around and carefully observing your objects of worship, I even found an altar on which had been inscribed, ‘To an unknown god.’ Now what you worship as unknown—this is what I am going to proclaim to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The God who made the world and everything in it is the Lord of heaven and earth and does not live in temples made with hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Neither is he served by human hands, as if he needed anything, since he himself gives all people life and breath and everything they have.
speaker: Narrator

text: From one man, he made every nation of mankind to live over the entire face of the earth. He determined the appointed times and the boundaries where they would live.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did this so they would seek God and perhaps reach out for him and find him, though he is not far from each one of us.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘For in him we live and move and have our being.’ As some of your own poets have said, ‘Indeed, we are also his offspring.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, since we are God’s offspring, we should not think that the divine being is like gold or silver or stone, an image formed by human skill and planning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Although God overlooked the times of ignorance, he is now commanding all people everywhere to repent,
speaker: Narrator

text: because he has set a day on which he is going to judge the world in righteousness by the man he appointed. He provided proof of this to everyone by raising him from the dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard about the resurrection from the dead, some of them started to scoff. But others said, “We want to hear you again on this subject.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Paul left the council.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, some men became followers of Paul and believed. Among them were Dionysius (a member of the council of the Areopagus) and a woman named Damaris, as well as others with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Paul left Athens and went to Corinth.
speaker: Narrator

text: There he found a Jew named Aquila, a native of Pontus, who had recently come from Italy with his wife Priscilla, because Claudius had ordered all the Jews to leave Rome. Paul went to see them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because he had the same occupation, he stayed and worked with them, for they were tentmakers by trade.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every Sabbath he led a discussion in the synagogue, trying to persuade both Jews and Greeks.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Silas and Timothy came down from Macedonia, Paul was entirely devoted to preaching the word, testifying to the Jews that Jesus was the Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they opposed Paul and slandered him, he shook out his clothes and said to them, “Your blood be on your own heads! I am innocent. From now on, I will go to the Gentiles!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He left that place and went to the house of a man named Titius Justus, a worshipper of God, whose house was next door to the synagogue.
speaker: Narrator

text: Crispus, the synagogue leader, believed in the Lord, together with his entire household. And many of the Corinthians, when they heard, believed and were baptized.
speaker: Narrator

text: One night the Lord spoke to Paul in a vision: “Do not be afraid, but keep on speaking, and do not be silent.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I am with you, and no one will lay a hand on you to harm you, because I have many people in this city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He stayed there a year and six months, teaching the word of God among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But while Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jews made a united attack on Paul and brought him before the judicial bench.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “This man is persuading the people to worship God in a way that is against the law.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But just as Paul was about to speak, Gallio said to the Jews, “If this were some kind of misdemeanor or vicious crime, I would formally accept the complaint of you Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: But since these are disputes about words and names and your own law, see to it yourselves. I do not intend to be a judge of these things.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he drove them away from the judicial bench.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the Greeks seized Sosthenes, the synagogue leader, and beat him in front of the judicial bench. But none of these things concerned Gallio.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Paul stayed many more days, he said good-bye to the brothers and sailed for Syria, accompanied by Priscilla and Aquila. At Cenchrea Paul had his head shaved, because he was keeping a vow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next they arrived at Ephesus, where he left Priscilla and Aquila. Paul himself went into the synagogue and led a discussion with the Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they asked him to stay for a longer time, he declined.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as he said good-bye, he told them, “I will come back to you again if it is God’s will.” Then he set sail from Ephesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he landed at Caesarea, he went up and greeted the church. Then he went down to Antioch.
speaker: Narrator

text: After spending some time there, he set out, traveling through one place after another in the region of Galatia and Phrygia, strengthening all the disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: A Jew named Apollos, a native of Alexandria, came to Ephesus. He was an eloquent man and well versed in the Scriptures.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had been instructed in the way of the Lord. He spoke with burning zeal and taught the facts about Jesus accurately, although he knew only the baptism of John.
speaker: Narrator

text: He began to speak boldly in the synagogue. But when Priscilla and Aquila heard him, they took him home and explained to him the way of God more accurately.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he wanted to cross over to Achaia, the brothers encouraged him and wrote to the disciples to welcome him. When he arrived, he provided much help to those who had become believers by grace,
speaker: Narrator

text: because he vigorously refuted the Jews in public, proving from the Scriptures that Jesus was the Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Apollos was at Corinth, Paul traveled through the interior districts and came to Ephesus. There he found some disciples
speaker: Narrator

text:
and asked them, “Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you became believers?”
“No,” they answered, “we have not even heard that the Holy Spirit was given.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Paul asked, “What were you baptized into then?”
They replied, “Into John’s baptism.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said, “John baptized with a baptism of repentance, telling the people to believe in the one coming after him, that is, in Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard this, they were baptized into the name of the Lord Jesus.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Paul laid his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came on them, and they began to speak in other languages and to prophesy.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were about twelve men in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul entered the synagogue and spoke boldly for three months, leading discussions and trying to persuade them about the kingdom of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when some became hardened and refused to believe, even slandering the Way in front of the crowd, he left them. He took the disciples with him and led discussions every day in the lecture hall of Tyrannus.
speaker: Narrator

text: This went on for two years, with the result that all who lived in the province of Asia, both Jews and Greeks, heard the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: God was doing extraordinary miracles through Paul,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that even handkerchiefs or aprons that had touched his skin were carried away to the sick; their illnesses left them and the evil spirits went out of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then some Jewish exorcists who went from place to place tried to invoke the name of the Lord Jesus over those who had evil spirits. They said, “I command you by the Jesus whom Paul preaches to come out!”
speaker: Narrator

text: It was the seven sons of Sceva, a Jewish chief priest, who were doing this.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the evil spirit answered them, “Jesus I know, and I am acquainted with Paul, but who are you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man who had the evil spirit jumped on them, overpowered them, and exercised such complete domination over all of them that they fled from that house naked and wounded.
speaker: Narrator

text: This became known to everyone who lived in Ephesus, both Jews and Greeks. They were all overcome with fear, and they held the name of the Lord Jesus in high honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also many of those who had become believers came forward, confessing and admitting their actions.
speaker: Narrator

text: And a large number of those who had practiced magic arts collected their books and burned them in front of everyone. They added up the cost of the books and found it to be fifty thousand pieces of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way the word of the Lord was growing and gaining strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: After all this had happened, Paul resolved in his spirit to go to Jerusalem by traveling through Macedonia and Achaia. “After I have been there,” he said, “I must also see Rome.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After sending two of his assistants, Timothy and Erastus, to Macedonia, he stayed in the province of Asia for a while.
speaker: Narrator

text: During that time there was more than a minor disturbance about the Way.
speaker: Narrator

text: A certain silversmith named Demetrius, who made silver shrines of Artemis, brought in no little income for the craftsmen.
speaker: Narrator

text: He called them together, along with the workers in similar trades, and said, “Men, you know that our prosperity comes from this income.
speaker: Narrator

text: You also see and hear that not merely in Ephesus but throughout almost the entire province of Asia, this Paul has persuaded and turned away a large number of people. He says that gods made by hands are not gods at all!
speaker: Narrator

text: Not only is there danger that our trade may be discredited, but also that the temple of the great goddess Artemis may be considered worthless. Then she will suffer the loss of her magnificence, although she is worshipped by the whole province of Asia and the world.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard this, they were filled with rage and began to shout, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The city was filled with confusion, and with one goal in mind they rushed to the theater, dragging along Gaius and Aristarchus, Macedonians who were Paul’s traveling companions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul wanted to enter the public assembly, but the disciples would not let him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even some of the provincial officials of Asia, who were his friends, sent him a message begging him not to venture into the theater.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some were shouting one thing, others another, because the assembly was in confusion. Most of them did not even know why they had come together.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made Alexander come out of the crowd. It was the Jews who pushed him forward. Alexander motioned with his hand and wanted to make his defense to the assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they recognized that he was a Jew, a single cry rose from all of them. For about two hours, they kept shouting, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
speaker: Narrator

text: After the town clerk had quieted the crowd, he said, “Men of Ephesus, who is there who does not know that the city of the Ephesians is the keeper of the temple of the great Artemis and of her image that fell from heaven?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, since these things cannot be denied, you need to be quiet and not do anything rash.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you have brought these men here who are neither temple robbers nor blasphemers of our goddess.
speaker: Narrator

text: If Demetrius and his fellow craftsmen have a complaint against anyone, the courts are open, and there are proconsuls. Let them press charges against one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you want to pursue something about other matters, it should be settled in the legal assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we are in danger of being charged with rioting today, because we will not be able to give any reason for this disorderly mob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had said this, he dismissed the assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the uproar had ended, Paul sent for the disciples and encouraged them. After saying good-bye, he left to go to Macedonia.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had gone through those areas and had spoken many words of encouragement to the people, he came to Greece
speaker: Narrator

text:
and stayed there three months.
Because a plot was made against him by the Jews just as he was about to set sail for Syria, he decided to go back through Macedonia.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was accompanied by Sopater son of Pyrrhus from Berea, Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessalonica, Gaius from Derbe, Timothy, along with Tychicus and Trophimus from the province of Asia.
speaker: Narrator

text: These men went on ahead and waited for us at Troas.
speaker: Narrator

text: We sailed from Philippi after the days of Unleavened Bread, and within five days we came to them at Troas, where we stayed seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of the week, when we were gathered together to break bread, Paul spoke to the people. Since he intended to leave the next day, he continued talking until midnight.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were many lamps in the upstairs room where we were gathered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seated in a window was a young man named Eutychus. He was sinking into a deep sleep as Paul kept on talking for a long time. When he was sound asleep, he fell down from the third story and was picked up dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul went down, bent over him, threw his arms around him, and said, “Do not be alarmed, because he is alive!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went upstairs, broke bread, and ate. After talking for a considerable time until dawn, he left.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought the boy home alive and were greatly comforted.
speaker: Narrator

text: We went on ahead to the ship and sailed for Assos, where we were going to take Paul aboard. He had arranged it this way, since he was intending to travel there by land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he met us at Assos, we took him on board and went to Mitylene.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there we set sail. We arrived off Chios the next day. The day after that we crossed over to Samos, and on the following day we came to Miletus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus, so that he would not have to spend time in the province of Asia. He was in a hurry to be in Jerusalem, if possible, by the day of Pentecost.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Miletus, Paul sent to Ephesus and called for the elders of the church.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to him, he said to them, “You know how I lived the whole time I was with you, from the first day I set foot in the province of Asia.
speaker: Narrator

text: I served the Lord with all humility, with tears, and with the trials that came to me due to the plots of the Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know how I did not hesitate to proclaim to you anything that would be beneficial for you or to teach you publicly and from house to house.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have solemnly testified to both Jews and Greeks about repentance toward God and faith in our Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And you see, now I am going to Jerusalem, compelled by the Spirit, not knowing what will happen to me there,
speaker: Narrator

text: except that the Holy Spirit keeps warning me in town after town that chains and afflictions are waiting for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, I consider my life as of no great value to me, so that I may finish my race and the ministry I received from the Lord Jesus—to testify to the gospel of God’s grace.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now take note of this too. I know that none of you among whom I went around preaching the kingdom of God will ever see my face again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I solemnly declare to you today that I am innocent of the blood of all of you,
speaker: Narrator

text: for I did not hesitate to proclaim to you the whole counsel of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Always keep watch over yourselves and over the whole flock in which the Holy Spirit has placed you as overseers, to shepherd the church of God, which he purchased with his own blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know that after my departure savage wolves, who will not spare the flock, will come in among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even from your own group men will rise up, twisting the truth in order to draw away disciples after them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore be always on the alert! Remember that for three years, night and day, I never stopped warning each one of you with tears.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now I entrust you to God and to the word of his grace, which has power to build you up and to give you an inheritance among all those who are sanctified.
speaker: Narrator

text: I did not covet anyone’s silver or gold or clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: You yourselves know that these hands have provided for my needs and for those who were with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: In every way I gave you an example that, by working hard like this, we need to help the weak and to remember the words that the Lord Jesus himself said: ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: After Paul said these things, he knelt down with all of them and prayed.
speaker: Narrator

text: They all wept very much, as they threw their arms around Paul’s neck and kissed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were most distressed over the statement he made, that they would never see his face again. Then they accompanied him to the ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: After we tore ourselves away from them and set sail, we headed straight to Cos, and the next day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we found a ship crossing over to Phoenicia, we went on board and set sail.
speaker: Narrator

text: After sighting Cyprus and passing by on its south side, we sailed to Syria and put in to port at Tyre, because there the ship was to unload its cargo.
speaker: Narrator

text: We located the disciples and stayed there seven days. Through the Spirit, they kept telling Paul not to go to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When our time there came to an end, we left and went on our way. All of them, with their wives and children, accompanied us out of the city. We knelt down on the beach and prayed.
speaker: Narrator

text: After saying good-bye to each other, we went on board the ship, and they returned home.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we completed our voyage from Tyre, we arrived at Ptolemais. There we greeted the brothers and stayed with them for one day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, we left and came to Caesarea. We entered the house of Philip the evangelist, who was one of the Seven, and stayed with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had four virgin daughters, who prophesied.
speaker: Narrator

text: After we had stayed there for a number of days, a prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came to us, he took Paul’s belt, tied his own feet and hands with it, and said, “This is what the Holy Spirit says: ‘This is the way the Jews at Jerusalem will bind the man who owns this belt and will deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When we heard this, both we and the local residents urged Paul not to go up to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul answered, “What are you doing, weeping and breaking my heart? For I am ready not only to be bound but also to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Since he could not be persuaded, we said nothing more except, “May the Lord’s will be done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After those days we got ready and went up to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the disciples from Caesarea also went with us and brought us to Mnason, with whom we were to stay. He was from Cyprus and was one of the first disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we arrived in Jerusalem, the brothers gave us a warm welcome.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, Paul went with us to see James, and all the elders were present.
speaker: Narrator

text: After greeting them, he reported in detail each of the things God had done among the Gentiles through his ministry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When they heard this, they praised God.
Then they said to him, “You see, brother, how many thousands there are among the Jews who have believed, and all of them are zealous observers of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have been informed that you teach all the Jews who live among the Gentiles to turn away from Moses, since you are telling them not to circumcise their children or follow our customs.
speaker: Narrator

text: So what is to be done? They will certainly hear that you have come.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So do what we are going to tell you.
“We have four men who have taken a vow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take them with you, go through the ceremony of purification with them, and pay their expenses so that they can have their heads shaved. Then everyone will know that there is nothing to the reports that have been made about you, but that you yourself are carefully following the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the Gentiles who believe, we have sent them a letter about the resolution that they should avoid food sacrificed to idols, blood, the meat of strangled animals, and sexual immorality.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, Paul took the men and went through the ceremony of purification with them. He entered the temple to announce the date when the days of purification would end and the offering would be made for each of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the seven days were almost over, Jews from the province of Asia saw Paul in the temple. They stirred up the whole crowd and seized him,
speaker: Narrator

text: shouting, “Men of Israel, help! This is the man who teaches everyone everywhere against our people and our law, and against this place. And now he has even brought Greeks into the temple and has defiled this holy place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (They had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian in the city with him and assumed that Paul had brought him into the temple.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole city was stirred up, and the people rushed together as a mob. They seized Paul, dragged him out of the temple, and immediately the gates were shut.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were looking for a way to kill him, a report went up to the commander of the cohort that all Jerusalem was in an uproar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He immediately took soldiers and centurions and ran down to them. When they saw the commander and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the commander approached Paul, arrested him, and gave an order that he should be bound with two chains. He asked who Paul was and what he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some in the crowd were shouting one thing and some another. Since the commander could not find out the truth because of the uproar, he ordered his men to take Paul away to the barracks.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came to the steps, Paul had to be carried by the soldiers because of the violence of the mob.
speaker: Narrator

text: The large number of people that was following kept shouting, “Away with him!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
As Paul was about to be brought into the barracks, he asked the commander, “May I say something to you?”
He replied, “Do you know Greek?
speaker: Narrator

text: Are you not the Egyptian who started a revolt some time ago and led four thousand men of the Assassins into the wilderness?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said, “I am a Jew, from Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of no insignificant city. I beg you, allow me to speak to the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the commander had given him permission, Paul stood on the steps and motioned with his hand to the people. When they were all silent, Paul addressed them in the Hebrew dialect.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Gentlemen, brothers, and fathers, listen to my defense, which I am now going to make to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When they heard that he was addressing them in the Hebrew dialect, they became even more quiet.
Then he said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am a Jew, born in Tarsus of Cilicia, but brought up in this city and trained at the feet of Gamaliel, according to the strict ways of the law of our fathers. I am just as zealous for God as all of you are today.
speaker: Narrator

text: I persecuted this Way to the death, tying up and throwing both men and women into prisons,
speaker: Narrator

text: as also the high priest and the whole council of elders can testify about me. I even received letters from them to the brothers, and I was going to Damascus to bring back those who were there as prisoners to Jerusalem so that they could be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: “While I was on the way and approaching Damascus, about noon a very bright light from heaven suddenly flashed around me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I answered, ‘Who are you, Lord?’
“He said to me, ‘I am Jesus the Nazarene, whom you are persecuting.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Those who were with me saw the light, but they did not understand the voice of the one who was speaking to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I said, ‘What shall I do, Lord?’
“The Lord said to me, ‘Get up and go into Damascus. There you will be told about everything you have been assigned to do.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Since I could not see because of the brightness of that light, those who were with me took me by the hand and led me into Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A man named Ananias lived there. He was a devout observer of the law and highly recommended by all the Jews living there.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came to me, and as he stood beside me, he said, ‘Brother Saul, receive your sight!’ At that very moment I was able to see him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then he said, ‘The God of our fathers has chosen you to know his will and to see the Righteous One and to hear the sound of his voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you will be his witness to all people of what you have seen and heard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now what are you waiting for? Get up, be baptized, and wash away your sins, calling on his name.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “When I returned to Jerusalem and was praying in the temple, I fell into a trance.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw the Lord telling me: ‘Hurry, get out of Jerusalem quickly, because they will not accept your testimony about me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “I said, ‘Lord, these people know that I went from one synagogue to another imprisoning and beating those who believed in you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the blood of your witness Stephen was shed, I stood by, giving my approval and guarding the clothes of those who were putting him to death.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the Lord said to me, ‘Go, because I will send you far away to the Gentiles.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: They were listening to Paul until he said this. Then they raised their voices, shouting, “Rid the earth of this fellow, for he is not fit to live!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they started shouting and throwing off their cloaks and throwing dust into the air,
speaker: Narrator

text: the commander ordered that Paul be brought into the barracks. He directed that Paul be interrogated by whipping, in order to learn why the people were shouting at him like this.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they stretched him for the whipping, Paul asked the centurion standing by, “Is it legal for you to whip a man who is a Roman citizen and who has not been found guilty by a proper trial?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the centurion heard this, he went to the commander and said, “What are you about to do? This man is a Roman citizen!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The commander came and asked him, “Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?”
He answered, “Yes.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the commander answered, “I acquired this citizenship for a large sum of money.”
Paul said, “But I was born a citizen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Immediately, those who were about to interrogate him moved away from him. The commander was also alarmed when he realized that Paul was a Roman citizen, because he had tied him up.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, since the commander wanted to find out exactly why Paul was being accused by the Jews, he untied him and ordered the chief priests and all the Sanhedrin to meet. Then he brought Paul down and had him stand before them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul looked straight at the Sanhedrin and said, “Gentlemen, brothers, I have lived my life before God with a completely clear conscience to this very day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the high priest Ananias ordered those who were standing near Paul to strike him on the mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul said to him, “God is going to strike you, you whitewashed wall! You sit there judging me according to the law, and then you order them to strike me contrary to the law!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who were standing nearby said, “Do you dare to insult God’s high priest?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul replied, “I did not know, brothers, that he is the high priest. Indeed, it is written, ‘You shall not speak evil about a ruler of your people.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Paul realized that some of them were Sadducees and the others were Pharisees, he shouted out in the Sanhedrin, “Gentlemen, brothers, I am a Pharisee, a son of Pharisees. I am on trial concerning the hope for the resurrection of the dead!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he said this, a dispute broke out between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the assembly was divided.
speaker: Narrator

text: (For the Sadducees say there is no resurrection or angel or spirit, but the Pharisees believe in them all.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then there was a great uproar, and some of the experts in the law who belonged to the party of the Pharisees stood up and protested strongly: “We find nothing wrong with this man. What if a spirit or an angel spoke to him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The uproar became so great that the commander was afraid Paul would be torn to pieces by them. He commanded the soldiers to go down, take him away from them by force, and bring him into the barracks.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following night the Lord stood next to Paul and said, “Take courage! As you have solemnly testified about me in Jerusalem, so you must also testify in Rome.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When day came, the Jews formed a conspiracy and bound themselves with an oath, saying that they would not eat or drink until they had killed Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were more than forty who took part in this plot.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went to the chief priests and elders and said, “We have bound ourselves under a solemn oath not to taste anything until we have killed Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, you and the Sanhedrin file charges with the commander so that he will bring him down to you as if you were going to make a more thorough examination of his case. We are ready to kill him before he gets close to this place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the son of Paul’s sister heard about the ambush, he went into the barracks and told Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul called one of the centurions and said, “Take this young man to the commander, because he has something to report to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he brought him to the commander and said, “The prisoner Paul called for me and asked me to bring this young man to you, because he has something to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The commander took him by the hand, led him aside, and asked him privately, “What is it that you have to tell me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “The Jews have agreed to ask you to bring Paul down to the Sanhedrin tomorrow, as if they want to gain more accurate information about him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t let them persuade you, because more than forty of their men are waiting in ambush for him. They have bound themselves under a solemn oath not to eat or drink until they have killed him. They are ready right now, waiting for your consent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the commander dismissed the young man with this order: “Don’t tell anyone that you have reported these things to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he called two of the centurions and said, “Get two hundred soldiers ready, along with seventy cavalry and two hundred spearmen, to go as far as Caesarea at the third hour of the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also provide mounts so that they can put Paul on one and bring him safely to Felix the governor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He wrote a letter as follows:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Claudius Lysias,
To his Excellency, Governor Felix:
Greetings.
speaker: Narrator

text: This man was seized by the Jews and was about to be killed by them when I came with the soldiers and rescued him, because I learned that he is a Roman citizen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since I wanted to know the charge they were bringing against him, I brought him down to their Sanhedrin.
speaker: Narrator

text: I found he was being accused concerning questions of their law, but there was no charge that deserved death or imprisonment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I was informed that there would be a plot against this man, I sent him to you at once. I also ordered his accusers to state what they have against him before you.
Farewell.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the soldiers, according to their orders, took Paul and brought him to Antipatris during the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day they let the cavalry go on with him, while they returned to the barracks.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the cavalry came to Caesarea, they delivered the letter to the governor, and they handed Paul over to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the governor had read the letter, he asked what province he was from. When he learned that he was from Cilicia,
speaker: Narrator

text: he said, “I will give you a hearing when your accusers arrive.” Then he ordered that Paul should be kept under guard in Herod’s palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Five days later the high priest Ananias came down with some elders and a lawyer named Tertullus. They brought formal charges against Paul to the governor.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Paul was called in, Tertullus began to accuse him, saying, “We are enjoying a long period of peace because of you, most excellent Felix, and reforms are coming to this nation because of your foresight.
speaker: Narrator

text: In every way and in every place, we acknowledge this with all gratitude.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in order not to detain you any longer, I beg you in your kindness to give us a brief hearing.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we have found this man to be a public menace, one who stirs up riots among all the Jews throughout the world, and a ringleader of the Nazarene sect.
speaker: Narrator

text: He even tried to desecrate the temple, so we arrested him.
speaker: Narrator

text: By examining him yourself, you will be able to learn from him about all these accusations we are bringing against him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jews also joined in the attack, asserting that these things were so.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the governor motioned to him to speak, Paul replied, “Because I know that you have been a judge over this nation for many years, I gladly make my defense.
speaker: Narrator

text: You can verify for yourself that it was no more than twelve days ago when I went up to worship at Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: They did not find me arguing with anyone in the temple or stirring up a crowd in the synagogues or anywhere else in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they cannot prove to you the accusations they are now making against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But I do confess to you that I worship the God of our fathers according to the Way, which they call a sect. I believe everything written throughout the Law and in the Prophets;
speaker: Narrator

text: and I have the same hope in God that these men have, that there is going to be a resurrection of both the righteous and the unrighteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the reason I continue to do my best to have a clear conscience toward both God and people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “After several years, I came to bring my people gifts for the poor and to present offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: While I was doing these things, they found me ceremonially purified in the temple, without a crowd or disturbance.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there are some Jews from the province of Asia who ought to be here before you and bring charges, if they have anything against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or let these men here state what crime they found in me when I stood before the Sanhedrin,
speaker: Narrator

text: unless this is about the one thing I shouted while standing in their presence: ‘It is concerning the resurrection of the dead that I am on trial before you today.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Felix, because he was rather well informed about the Way, adjourned the proceedings. He said, “When Lysias the commander comes down, I will decide your case.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He ordered the centurion to guard Paul, but to let him have some freedom and not to prevent any of his friends from taking care of his needs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Several days later, Felix appeared in public with his wife Drusilla, who was Jewish. He sent for Paul and listened to him speak about faith in Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Paul instructed him about righteousness, self-control, and the coming judgment, Felix became frightened and replied, “Leave me for now, but when it is convenient, I will send for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At the same time, he was also hoping that Paul would give him money, and for this reason he sent for him as often as possible and talked with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After two years had passed, Felix was succeeded by Portius Festus. But because he wanted to do the Jews a favor, Felix left Paul in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days after Festus arrived in the province, he went up to Jerusalem from Caesarea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the high priests and the leaders of the Jews brought formal charges against Paul
speaker: Narrator

text: and asked Festus for the favor of transferring Paul’s case to Jerusalem. Their plan was to ambush and kill Paul along the way.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, Festus replied that Paul was being held in custody at Caesarea and that he himself intended to go there soon.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore,” he said, “let some of your leaders go down with me and press charges against him, if there is anything evil about the man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After spending no more than eight or ten days among them, he went down to Caesarea. The next day, he sat on the judicial bench and ordered Paul to be brought in.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he arrived, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around him and brought many serious charges that they could not prove.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said in his defense, “I have not committed any offense against the Jewish law, against the temple, or against Caesar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But since Festus wanted to do the Jews a favor, he said to Paul, “Are you willing to go up to Jerusalem and stand trial before me there on these charges?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul said, “I am standing before Caesar’s judicial bench, where I ought to be tried. I have done nothing wrong to the Jews, as also you yourself know very well.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I am guilty and have done something worthy of death, I am not trying to escape death. But if there is nothing to the charges they are making against me, no one can hand me over to them. I appeal to Caesar!”
speaker: Narrator

text: After Festus conferred with his council, he answered, “You have appealed to Caesar. To Caesar you will go!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Some days later, King Agrippa and Bernice arrived at Caesarea to pay their respects to Festus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since they were going to stay there a number of days, Festus laid Paul’s case before the king. He said, “There is a man who was left as a prisoner by Felix.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I was in Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews brought charges against him and asked for a sentence of condemnation against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I answered them that it is not the Roman custom to hand over any man before the accused has met the accusers face to face and has had an opportunity to make a defense against the accusation.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, after they came back here with me, I did not delay. On the next day I took my place on the judicial bench and ordered the man to be brought in.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the accusers stood up, they charged him with none of the crimes I was expecting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, they had some points of dispute with him about their own religion and about a certain Jesus who was dead, but who Paul claimed is alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since I was at a loss how to investigate these issues, I asked if he was willing to go to Jerusalem to be tried there concerning these charges.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Paul appealed to be kept in custody until his majesty the emperor would decide his case, I ordered him to be held until I could send him to Caesar.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Agrippa said to Festus, “I would like to hear the man myself.”
“Tomorrow,” he said, “you will hear him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the next day Agrippa and Bernice came with great pomp and entered the courtroom together with the commanders and the most prominent men of the city. When Festus gave the order, Paul was brought in.
speaker: Narrator

text: Festus said, “King Agrippa and all the men who are present with us, you see this man about whom the whole Jewish crowd petitioned me, both in Jerusalem and here, shouting that he ought not to live any longer.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I found that he has done nothing that deserves death. Yet, since he appealed to his majesty the emperor, I decided to send him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have nothing definite to write to my lord about him. Therefore, I have brought him before all of you, and especially before you, King Agrippa, so that after this preliminary hearing I may have something to write.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, it seems unreasonable to me to send a prisoner without clearly indicating what the charges are against him.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Agrippa said to Paul, “You have permission to speak for yourself.”
Then Paul stretched out his hand and began his defense.
speaker: Narrator

text: “King Agrippa, I consider myself fortunate that I am going to make my defense before you today concerning all the things about which I am being accused by the Jews,
speaker: Narrator

text: especially because you are an expert in all the Jewish customs and controversies. Therefore, I beg you to listen to me patiently.
speaker: Narrator

text: “All the Jews know the way I have lived from the earliest days of my youth, among my own people and in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have known about me for a long time, if they are willing to testify, that I lived as a Pharisee according to the strictest party of our religion.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now I stand on trial because of my hope in the promise made by God to our fathers,
speaker: Narrator

text: the promise that our twelve tribes hope to attain as they earnestly serve God night and day. I am being accused by the Jews concerning this hope, O King.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why does it seem unbelievable to any of you that God raises the dead?
speaker: Narrator

text: “I too was convinced that it was necessary to do many things hostile to the name of Jesus the Nazarene.
speaker: Narrator

text: And that is what I did in Jerusalem. After receiving authority from the chief priests, I put many of the saints in prison, and when they were put to death, I cast my vote against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I often tried to make them blaspheme by punishing them throughout all the synagogues. Because I was so insanely angry with them, I even pursued them to foreign cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: “That is how I came to be traveling to Damascus with the authority and commission of the chief priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: At noon along the road, O King, I saw a light from heaven, brighter than the sun, shining around me and those traveling with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: We all fell to the ground, and I heard a voice saying to me in the Hebrew dialect, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? It is hard for you to kick against the goads.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Then I said, ‘Who are you, Lord?’
“The Lord replied, ‘I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now get up and stand on your feet, for I have appeared to you for this purpose: to appoint you as a servant and witness to the things you have seen and to the things I will reveal to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will rescue you from your people and from the Gentiles to whom I am sending you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to open their eyes, so that they may turn from darkness to light and from the power of Satan to God, so that they may receive the forgiveness of sins and a place among those who are sanctified by faith in me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the vision from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rather, I first told those in Damascus and Jerusalem about it, and then throughout the entire country of Judea and also the Gentiles. I told them that they should repent and turn to God, while also doing works that are consistent with repentance.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the reasons the Jews seized me in the temple and tried to kill me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But I have had help from God right up to this day, and so I stand testifying to both small and great. I am saying nothing other than what the prophets and Moses said would happen,
speaker: Narrator

text: that the Christ would suffer and, as the first to rise from the dead, he would proclaim light to our people and to the Gentiles.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While Paul was saying these things in his defense, Festus shouted, “Paul, you are out of your mind! Your great learning is driving you insane.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul replied, “I am not insane, most excellent Festus, but I am clearly speaking words that are true and sensible.
speaker: Narrator

text: Certainly the king to whom I am freely speaking knows about these things. Indeed, I cannot believe that any of these things has escaped his notice, because this has not been done in a corner.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know that you believe.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Agrippa said to Paul, “In such a short time are you going to persuade me to become a Christian?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul replied, “I pray God, that whether in a short time or a long time, not only you, but also all those who are listening to me today would become what I am, except for these chains.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had said these things, the king stood up, along with the governor and Bernice and those sitting with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they had left, they said to one another in private, “This man is doing nothing worthy of death or chains.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Agrippa said to Festus, “This man could have been set free if he had not appealed to Caesar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was decided that we would sail for Italy, Paul and some other prisoners were handed over to a centurion named Julius, of the Imperial Regiment.
speaker: Narrator

text: After boarding a ship from Adramyttium, which was going to sail for ports along the coast of the province of Asia, we put out to sea. Aristarchus, a Macedonian from Thessalonica, was with us.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, we put in at Sidon, and Julius treated Paul kindly and allowed him to go to his friends to receive their care.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there we put out to sea and sailed on the sheltered side of Cyprus, because the winds were against us.
speaker: Narrator

text: We crossed the open sea along the coast of Cilicia and Pamphylia and landed at Myra in Lycia.
speaker: Narrator

text: There the centurion found an Alexandrian ship sailing for Italy, and he put us on board.
speaker: Narrator

text: We sailed slowly for a number of days and arrived with difficulty off Cnidus. Since the wind did not permit us to go further, we sailed on the sheltered side of Crete, off Salmone.
speaker: Narrator

text: With difficulty we sailed along its coast and came to a place called Fair Havens, near the city of Lasea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since so much time had passed and the voyage was now dangerous because the Fast was already over, Paul advised them,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Men, it looks to me as if the voyage is going to end with disaster and great loss, not only of the cargo and the ship but also of our lives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the centurion paid more attention to the pilot and the owner of the ship than to what Paul was saying.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since that harbor was unsuitable to winter in, the majority decided to put out to sea from there, hoping somehow to reach Phoenix and winter there. (Phoenix is a harbor on Crete, facing both southwest and northwest.)
speaker: Narrator

text: When a gentle south wind began to blow, they thought they could carry out their plan. They raised the anchor and sailed close to the shore of Crete.
speaker: Narrator

text: But before long, a hurricane-like wind, called the “northeaster,” rushed down from the island.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since the ship was caught in it and could not head into the wind, we gave way to it and were driven along.
speaker: Narrator

text: As we sailed on the sheltered side of a small island called Cauda, we were barely able to secure the skiff.
speaker: Narrator

text: After hoisting it on board, the men tied ropes around the ship to reinforce it. Then, fearing that they would run aground on the sandbars of Syrtis, they lowered the sea anchor and in this way were driven along.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because we were tossed around so violently by the storm, the next day they began to throw the cargo overboard.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day, they threw the ship’s gear overboard with their own hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: When neither sun nor stars appeared for many days and the violent storm kept pressing down on us, finally all hope that we would be saved was disappearing.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they had gone a long time without food, Paul stood up among them and said, “Men, you should have followed my advice and not set sail from Crete and avoided this damage and loss.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now I urge you to keep up your courage, because there will be no loss of life among you. Only the ship will be lost.
speaker: Narrator

text: In fact, last night an angel of the God to whom I belong and whom I serve stood beside me
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, ‘Do not be afraid, Paul. You must stand before Caesar. And surely God has graciously given you all those who are sailing with you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So keep up your courage, men, because I believe God that it will be exactly the way I have been told.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, we must run aground on some island.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the fourteenth night came, while we were being driven back and forth in the Adriatic Sea, about midnight the sailors suspected that they were approaching some land.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took soundings and found it to be one hundred twenty feet deep. After sailing a little farther, they took soundings again and found it was ninety feet deep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fearing that we would run aground on the rocks, they dropped four anchors from the stern and prayed for daybreak.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sailors tried to escape from the ship and had let down the skiff into the sea, pretending they were going to put out anchors from the bow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, “If these men do not stay in the ship, you cannot be saved.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the soldiers cut the ropes holding the skiff and let it fall away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just before daybreak, Paul urged them all to eat some food. He said, “This is the fourteenth day you have waited in suspense and have gone without food. You have eaten nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I urge you to take some food because this is important for your rescue. In fact, not a hair from any of your heads will be lost.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After he said these things and had taken some bread, he gave thanks to God in front of them all. Then he broke it and began to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were all encouraged and took some food themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all there were 276 of us on the ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had eaten all they wanted, they lightened the ship by throwing the grain overboard into the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: At daybreak, they did not recognize the land, but they noticed a bay with a beach, where they planned to run the ship aground if they could.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cut off the anchors, leaving them in the sea, and at the same time untied the ropes that held the rudders. Then, after hoisting the foresail to the wind, they headed for the beach.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they struck a sandbar and ran the ship aground. The bow stuck fast and would not move, while the stern began to break up from the pounding of the waves.
speaker: Narrator

text: The soldiers’ plan was to kill the prisoners so that no one would swim away and escape.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the centurion wanted to save Paul and kept them from carrying out their plan. He ordered those who could swim to jump overboard first and make their way to land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest were to follow, some on planks, and some on other pieces from the ship. In this way, all of them were brought safely onto land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once we were safely on shore, we learned that the island was called Malta.
speaker: Narrator

text: The natives showed us extraordinary kindness. They built a fire and welcomed us all, because it had started to rain and was cold.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Paul gathered a bundle of sticks and laid it on the fire, a viper came out because of the heat and fastened itself on his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the natives saw the snake hanging from his hand, they said to one another, “No doubt this man is a murderer. Though he escaped from the sea, Justice has not allowed him to live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: However, Paul shook the snake off into the fire and was not harmed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people expected him to swell up or suddenly fall down dead. But after they had waited for a long time and saw nothing unusual happen to him, they changed their minds and said he was a god.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the nearby vicinity was an estate that belonged to a man named Publius, the chief official of the island. He welcomed us and entertained us hospitably as his guests for three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The father of Publius happened to be sick in bed, suffering from a fever and dysentery. Paul went to him, prayed, laid his hands on him, and healed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that happened, others on the island who were sick also came and were healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: They honored us in many ways, and when we were going to sail, they put on board whatever we needed.
speaker: Narrator

text: After three months, we set sail in an Alexandrian ship that had wintered at the island. Its figurehead was the Twin Brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: We put in at Syracuse and stayed there three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there we sailed up the coast and arrived at Rhegium. After one day a south wind sprang up, and on the second day we came to Puteoli.
speaker: Narrator

text: There we found some brothers and were invited to stay with them for seven days. And so we came to Rome.
speaker: Narrator

text: The brothers there heard the news about us and came as far as the Forum of Appius and Three Taverns to meet us. When Paul saw them, he thanked God and was encouraged.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we entered Rome, Paul was allowed to live by himself with a soldier who guarded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days later, Paul called together the leaders of the Jews. When they had assembled, he said to them, “Gentlemen, brothers, although I had done nothing against the people or the customs of our fathers, yet I was handed over as a prisoner from Jerusalem to the Romans.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they interrogated me, they wanted to release me, because there were no grounds for the death penalty in my case.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the Jews objected, I was compelled to appeal to Caesar—not that I had any charge to bring against my own people.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why I asked to see you and speak to you, since it is because of the hope of Israel that I am bound with this chain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “We have not received any letters about you from Judea, and none of the brothers who came here has reported or said anything evil about you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we would like to hear from you what you think, because we know that people everywhere are speaking against this sect.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They set a day to meet with Paul, and even more of them came to the place where he was staying. From morning till evening he explained and testified about the kingdom of God. He also tried to convince them about Jesus, both from the Law of Moses and the Prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some were convinced by what he said, but others continued in their unbelief.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were arguing with one another and began to leave after Paul made this one statement: “The Holy Spirit spoke the truth to your fathers through Isaiah the prophet:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For the heart of this people has grown dull,
their ears are hard of hearing,
and they have closed their eyes.
Otherwise they might see with their eyes,
hear with their ears,
understand with their heart,
and turn, and I would heal them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore let it be known to you that this salvation from God has been sent to the Gentiles, and they will listen!”
speaker: Narrator

text: For two whole years Paul stayed in his own rented house and welcomed all who came to visit him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was preaching the kingdom of God and teaching about the Lord Jesus Christ with all boldness and without anyone stopping him.
speaker: Narrator
